recipes.title: Fried Rice
recipes.desc: A delicious Nigerian recipe with fresh vegetables and a hint of spice.
ingredients: 5 medium sized Roma tomatoes, roughly chopped
1 medium sized onion, roughly chopped, set aside
2 scotch bonnet peppers (habanero peppers as they are sometimes called)
instructions: In a blender, combine the roughly chopped tomatoes, red bell pepper, and scotch bonnet peppers. Blend until smooth.
Heat the groundnut oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until translucent.
Add the blended tomato and pepper mixture to the pot and cook for about 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the mixture reduces and thickens.
Stir in the tomato paste, curry powder, thyme, all-purpose seasoning, salt, and Knorr stock cube. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Add the parboiled rice to the pot and stir until well coated with the tomato mixture.
Pour in the chicken stock and add the bay leaves. Stir to combine.

Cover the pot with a lid and simmer over low heat for about 25-30 minutes, or until the rice is cooked through and most of the liquid is absorbed. Check and stir occasionally to prevent burning, and add more water if necessary.
Once the rice is cooked, remove the pot from the heat and let it rest for a few minutes before serving.
Serve the Jollof Rice hot, garnished with your favorite toppings if desired. Enjoy!

recipes.title: Tagine
recipes.desc: A flavorful Moroccan dish cooked in a traditional tagine pot, featuring tender meat, aromatic spices, and dried fruits.
ingredients: 2 lbs chicken thighs, skinless and boneless
instructions: Heat olive oil in a tagine pot or large skillet over medium heat. Add chopped onions and minced garlic, and cook until softened.
Add chicken thighs to the pot and brown on all sides, about 5 minutes per side.
Stir in ground cumin, ground ginger, ground cinnamon, and ground turmeric, and cook for another minute until fragrant.
Pour in chicken broth and add dried apricots and prunes to the pot. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Cover the pot and simmer for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until the chicken is tender and cooked through.
In the last 10 minutes of cooking, sprinkle sliced almonds over the tagine and let them toast until golden brown.
Garnish the tagine with fresh cilantro before serving. Enjoy with couscous or bread!

recipes.title: Doro Wat
recipes.desc: A traditional Ethiopian chicken stew simmered in a rich and spicy sauce, flavored with berbere spice blend and served with injera bread.
ingredients: 2 lbs chicken thighs, bone-in and skin-on
instructions: In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add chopped onions and cook until softened.
Add minced garlic and grated ginger to the pot, and cook for another minute until fragrant.
Stir in berbere spice blend and tomato paste, and cook for 2-3 minutes to toast the spices.
Add chicken thighs to the pot and brown on all sides, about 5 minutes per side.
Pour in chicken broth, lemon juice, and honey. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Cover the pot and simmer for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until the chicken is tender and cooked through.
Garnish the Doro Wat with hard-boiled eggs and fresh cilantro before serving. Enjoy with injera bread!

recipes.title: Bobotie
recipes.desc: A traditional South African dish with spiced minced meat, topped with a creamy egg custard layer and baked until golden brown.
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a baking dish and set aside.
In a small bowl, soak white bread slices in milk until softened.
In a large skillet, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add chopped onions and cook until softened.
Add minced garlic and grated ginger to the skillet, and cook for another minute until fragrant.
Stir in curry powder, apricot jam, and lemon juice. Cook for 2-3 minutes to toast the spices.
Add ground beef or lamb to the skillet and cook until browned, breaking it up with a spoon.
Squeeze excess milk from soaked bread and add it to the skillet, along with raisins and chopped almonds. Mix well to combine.
Season the mixture with salt and pepper to taste. Transfer it to the prepared baking dish and spread it out evenly.
In a small bowl, beat eggs and pour them over the meat mixture in the baking dish. Arrange bay leaves on top.
Bake in the preheated oven for 30-40 minutes, until the egg custard layer is set and golden brown.
Remove from the oven and let it cool slightly before serving. Enjoy the Bobotie warm!

recipes.title: Ghanaian Jollof Rice
recipes.desc: A flavorful Ghanaian version of the popular Jollof Rice dish, cooked with fragrant spices, tomatoes, and vegetables.
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a baking dish and set aside.
In a large skillet, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add chopped onions and cook until softened.
Add chopped tomatoes, red bell pepper, green bell pepper, and scotch bonnet peppers to the skillet. Cook until softened and slightly caramelized.
Stir in tomato paste, thyme, curry powder, paprika, garlic powder, and ginger powder. Cook for another 2-3 minutes.
Add chicken drumsticks to the skillet and brown on all sides.
Transfer the chicken and vegetable mixture to the prepared baking dish. Spread it out evenly.
Rinse parboiled rice under cold water and add it to the baking dish, spreading it out evenly over the chicken and vegetables.
Pour chicken broth over the rice until it is fully submerged. Cover the baking dish tightly with aluminum foil.
Bake in the preheated oven for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until the rice is cooked through and the liquid is absorbed.
Remove from the oven and let it cool slightly before serving. Garnish with fresh parsley and serve the Jollof Rice hot!

recipes.title: Couscous
recipes.desc: A classic Tunisian dish featuring fluffy couscous served with a flavorful stew of vegetables, chickpeas, and tender meat.
ingredients: 1 lb lamb or beef stew meat, cubed
instructions: In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add chopped onions and cook until softened.
Add cubed stew meat to the pot and brown on all sides, about 5 minutes per side.
Stir in minced garlic, ground cumin, ground coriander, ground paprika, and ground cinnamon. Cook for another minute until fragrant.
Add chopped tomatoes, sliced carrots, sliced zucchini, and cooked chickpeas to the pot. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Pour chicken or vegetable broth over the mixture and bring to a simmer. Cover the pot and cook for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until the meat is tender.
Prepare couscous according to package instructions.
Serve the stewed meat and vegetables over fluffy couscous. Garnish with fresh cilantro before serving. Enjoy the Tunisian Couscous!

recipes.title: Ugali and Sukuma Wiki
recipes.desc: A staple Kenyan meal featuring Ugali, a dense cornmeal porridge, served with Sukuma Wiki, a flavorful collard greens stew.
instructions: In a large pot, bring water to a boil. Gradually add cornmeal to the boiling water, stirring constantly to prevent lumps from forming.
Reduce heat to low and continue stirring until the mixture thickens and pulls away from the sides of the pot, about 10-15 minutes.
Remove the pot from the heat and let the Ugali cool slightly. Using wet hands, shape the Ugali into balls or a mound.
In another pot, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add chopped onions and cook until softened.
Stir in minced garlic, ground cumin, ground coriander, and ground turmeric. Cook for another minute until fragrant.
Add chopped tomatoes and chopped collard greens to the pot. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Cover the pot and simmer for 15-20 minutes, until the collard greens are tender and cooked through.
Serve the Sukuma Wiki alongside the Ugali. Enjoy this traditional Kenyan meal!

recipes.title: Thieboudienne
recipes.desc: The national dish of Senegal, Thieboudienne is a flavorful rice and fish stew cooked in a rich tomato broth with vegetables and spices.
ingredients: 1 lb fish fillets (such as red snapper or tilapia)
instructions: In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add chopped onions and cook until softened.
Stir in minced garlic, ground ginger, ground thyme, ground cloves, and ground black pepper. Cook for another minute until fragrant.
Add chopped tomatoes and tomato paste to the pot. Cook until the tomatoes break down and form a thick sauce.
Add sliced carrots, sliced eggplant, diced sweet potato, chopped cabbage, and fish fillets to the pot. Season with salt to taste.
Pour enough water into the pot to cover the ingredients. Bring to a simmer and cook for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until the vegetables are tender and the fish is cooked through.
In the last 15 minutes of cooking, add washed long grain rice to the pot and stir to combine. Continue cooking until the rice is cooked through and most of the liquid is absorbed.
Remove from heat and let it rest for a few minutes before serving. Serve the Thieboudienne hot and enjoy this Senegalese delicacy!

recipes.title: Ndolé
recipes.desc: A traditional Cameroonian dish featuring bitter leaf greens cooked with groundnuts (peanuts), meat, and spices, served with rice or fufu.
ingredients: 2 cups bitter leaf greens, washed and chopped
instructions: In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add chopped onions and cook until softened.
Stir in minced garlic, ground ginger, ground cayenne pepper, ground nutmeg, and ground cloves. Cook for another minute until fragrant.
Add chopped tomatoes and bell pepper to the pot. Cook until the vegetables break down and form a thick sauce.
Add cubed beef or chicken to the pot and brown on all sides.
Stir in peanut butter and enough water to form a thick sauce. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Add chopped bitter leaf greens to the pot and stir to combine. Cover and simmer for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until the meat is tender and the flavors meld together.
Serve the Ndolé hot, accompanied by rice or fufu. Enjoy this flavorful Cameroonian dish!

recipes.title: Dholl Puri
recipes.desc: A popular street food in Mauritius, Dholl Puri is a type of flatbread made from ground split peas, served with a variety of savory fillings and chutneys.
ingredients: 2 cups yellow split peas, soaked overnight
instructions: Drain soaked split peas and rinse them under cold water. In a blender or food processor, grind the split peas into a coarse paste.
Transfer the ground split peas to a large bowl. Add all-purpose flour, ground turmeric, ground cumin, ground coriander, ground cinnamon, ground cloves, and salt to the bowl.
Knead the mixture into a smooth dough, adding water as needed to achieve the right consistency. Cover and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls and roll them out into thin circles on a lightly floured surface.
Heat a skillet or griddle over medium heat. Place the rolled-out dough on the skillet and cook until golden brown and cooked through, about 2-3 minutes per side.
Remove from the skillet and keep warm. Repeat with the remaining dough balls.
Serve the Dholl Puri hot, accompanied by various fillings such as curry, chutney, pickles, and fresh herbs. Enjoy this Mauritian street food delight!

recipes.title: Chakalaka
recipes.desc: Chakalaka is a South African vegetable relish, usually spicy, that is traditionally served with bread, pap, samp, stews, or curries.
ingredients: 1 can (14 oz) baked beans in tomato sauce
instructions: Heat the oil in a large skillet or pan over medium heat.
Add the onions, bell peppers, and chili peppers (if using). Cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in the garlic and grated carrots. Cook for another 2-3 minutes.
Add the baked beans and chopped tomatoes. Stir to combine.
Season with curry powder, paprika, salt, and pepper. Adjust seasoning to taste.
Simmer uncovered for about 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce thickens.
Serve hot as a side dish with bread, pap, samp, or other main dishes. Enjoy!

recipes.title: Injera
recipes.desc: Injera is a sourdough flatbread with a slightly spongy texture, commonly eaten in Ethiopia and Eritrea.
instructions: In a large mixing bowl, combine the teff flour, all-purpose flour, and salt. Gradually add water, stirring continuously, until a smooth batter forms. The batter should be thin and pourable.
Cover the bowl with a clean kitchen towel and let it sit at room temperature for at least 8 hours or overnight to ferment.
After fermenting, the batter should be bubbly and slightly sour-smelling.
Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over medium heat. Lightly oil the surface.
Pour a ladleful of batter onto the skillet and quickly swirl it around to spread it into a thin, even layer.
Cook for 1-2 minutes, until the edges start to lift and the surface appears dry.
Carefully transfer the injera to a plate and repeat with the remaining batter, stacking the cooked injera on top of each other.
Serve warm with your favorite Ethiopian/Eritrean dishes. Enjoy!

recipes.title: Bunny Chow
recipes.desc: Bunny Chow is a South African fast food dish consisting of a hollowed-out loaf of bread filled with curry.
ingredients: 4 large white bread rolls or loaves
instructions: Cut a large rectangle out of the top of each bread roll and hollow out the insides to create a bowl. Reserve the removed bread for serving.
Heat the vegetable oil in a large skillet or pan over medium heat.
Add the onion, garlic, and ginger. Sauté until softened, about 3-4 minutes.
Stir in the tomatoes, bell pepper, potatoes, carrot, and chickpeas. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Add the curry powder, cumin, coriander, turmeric, and chili powder. Cook for 1-2 minutes, until fragrant.
Pour in the vegetable broth or water. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender and the curry has thickened.
To serve, ladle the curry into the hollowed-out bread rolls. Garnish with fresh cilantro and serve with the reserved bread on the side. Enjoy!

recipes.title: Maafe
recipes.desc: Maafe, also known as groundnut stew, is a traditional West African dish made with meat, vegetables, and a rich peanut sauce.
ingredients: 1 lb meat (beef, chicken, or lamb), cut into bite-sized pieces
Cooked rice or couscous, for serving
instructions: Heat the vegetable oil in a large pot over medium heat.
Add the onion, garlic, and ginger. Sauté until softened, about 3-4 minutes.
Add the meat and cook until browned on all sides, about 5 minutes.
Stir in the tomatoes, sweet potato, eggplant, and bell pepper. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Add the peanut butter, vegetable broth or water, paprika, and cayenne pepper. Stir to combine.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 45-50 minutes, or until the meat is tender and the sauce has thickened.
Serve hot over cooked rice or couscous. Enjoy!

recipes.title: Pap en Vleis
recipes.desc: Pap en Vleis (also known as Shisa Nyama) is a traditional South African dish featuring pap (maize porridge) served with grilled meat and chakalaka.
instructions: In a large pot, bring the water to a boil. Add the salt.
Gradually stir in the maize meal, whisking continuously to prevent lumps from forming.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer, covered, for 20-25 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the pap is thick and smooth.
While the pap is cooking, prepare the meat. Season the ribs and boerewors with salt and pepper.
Grill the ribs and boerewors over medium-high heat until cooked to your liking, about 10-15 minutes.
Serve the pap hot with the grilled meat, sliced onion, and tomato. Enjoy with chakalaka on the side, if desired!

recipes.title: Moi Moi
recipes.desc: Moin Moin is a traditional Nigerian steamed bean pudding made from peeled black-eyed peas, onions, and spices.
ingredients: Banana leaves or foil, for wrapping
instructions: Rinse the black-eyed peas and soak them in water overnight, or for at least 6 hours.
Drain the soaked black-eyed peas and transfer them to a blender.
Add the chopped onion, garlic, bell pepper, scotch bonnet pepper, vegetable oil, crayfish (if using), dried shrimp (if using), paprika, cumin, and salt to the blender.
Blend until smooth, adding a little water if necessary to facilitate blending.
Preheat a steamer or pot with a steaming rack.
If using banana leaves, briefly pass them over an open flame to make them pliable. If using foil, cut it into squares.
Scoop a portion of the blended mixture onto a banana leaf or foil. Fold or wrap to form a packet.
Place the wrapped moin moin packets in the steamer or pot, making sure they're not crowded.
Steam for 45-60 minutes, or until the moin moin is firm and set.
Carefully unwrap and serve hot or warm. Enjoy!

recipes.title: Waakye
recipes.desc: Waakye is a popular Ghanaian dish made of rice and beans, typically served with stewed meat or fish, fried plantains, and spaghetti.
instructions: Rinse the rice and black-eyed peas separately under cold water.
In a large bowl, combine the rice and black-eyed peas. Cover with water and let soak for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the soaked rice and beans and transfer them to a large pot.
Add the water and baking soda to the pot. Bring to a boil over high heat.
Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until the rice and beans are tender.
Season with salt to taste.
Serve the waakye hot with stewed meat or fish, fried plantains, and spaghetti. Enjoy!

recipes.title: Jollof Spaghetti
recipes.desc: Jollof Spaghetti is a Nigerian twist on the popular West African Jollof Rice. It's made with spaghetti instead of rice, cooked in a flavorful tomato and pepper sauce.
ingredients: 1 cup cooked chicken or beef, shredded (optional)
Fresh parsley or green onions, chopped (for garnish)
instructions: Cook the spaghetti according to package instructions until al dente. Drain and set aside.
In a large skillet or pan, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat.
Add the chopped onion, red bell pepper, and green bell pepper. Sauté until softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in the tomato stew/sauce, cooked chicken or beef (if using), curry powder, thyme, paprika, salt, and pepper. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Add the cooked spaghetti to the skillet. Stir until well coated with the sauce.
Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the spaghetti is heated through and infused with the flavors of the sauce.
Garnish with chopped parsley or green onions before serving. Enjoy!

recipes.title: Cape Malay Curry
recipes.desc: Cape Malay Curry is a fragrant and spicy curry dish that originated in the Cape Malay community of South Africa. It's typically made with a blend of aromatic spices and served with rice.
ingredients: 1 cup green beans, trimmed and halved
instructions: In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat.
Add the onion, garlic, and ginger. Sauté until softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in the chopped tomatoes, curry powder, cumin, coriander, turmeric, cinnamon, cardamom, and cloves. Cook for another 2-3 minutes.
Pour in the vegetable broth and coconut milk. Bring to a simmer.
Add the diced potatoes and carrots to the pot. Cover and simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender.
Add the green beans to the pot. Simmer for an additional 5 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Garnish with chopped cilantro before serving. Enjoy with rice or bread!

recipes.title: Suya
recipes.desc: Suya is a popular West African street food made of skewered and grilled meat, typically seasoned with a spicy peanut marinade.
ingredients: 1 lb beef or chicken, thinly sliced
instructions: If using wooden skewers, soak them in water for at least 30 minutes to prevent burning.
In a bowl, combine the groundnut powder, cayenne pepper, paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, ginger powder, and salt to make the suya spice blend.
Thread the thinly sliced meat onto the skewers, folding and layering it to create even thickness.
Brush the meat skewers with vegetable oil.
Rub the suya spice blend onto the meat, coating it evenly on all sides.
Preheat a grill or grill pan to medium-high heat.
Grill the suya skewers for 5-7 minutes on each side, or until cooked through and slightly charred.
Serve hot with sliced onions and tomatoes. Enjoy the spicy, flavorful goodness of suya!

recipes.title: Chickpea Stew
recipes.desc: Moroccan Chickpea Stew is a hearty and comforting dish made with chickpeas, tomatoes, and a blend of warm spices. It's perfect for chilly evenings and pairs well with couscous or crusty bread.
ingredients: 1 can (14 oz) chickpeas, drained and rinsed
Fresh cilantro or parsley, chopped (for garnish)
instructions: In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat the olive oil over medium heat.
Add the chopped onion, garlic, and ginger. Sauté until softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in the chickpeas, diced tomatoes, vegetable broth, sweet potato, carrot, zucchini, cumin, coriander, cinnamon, turmeric, salt, and pepper.
Bring the stew to a simmer, then reduce the heat to low. Cover and simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender.
Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary.
Garnish with chopped cilantro or parsley before serving. Enjoy with couscous or crusty bread!

recipes.title: Chapati
recipes.desc: Chapati is a type of unleavened flatbread that originated in India but is also popular in East African cuisine. Kenyan Chapati is soft, flaky, and delicious, perfect for scooping up stews and curries.
instructions: In a large bowl, combine the all-purpose flour and salt.
Make a well in the center of the flour mixture and pour in the warm water and vegetable oil.
Mix until a dough forms, adding more flour or water if necessary to achieve a smooth, elastic consistency.
Divide the dough into equal-sized balls. Roll each ball into a thin circle on a lightly floured surface, using a rolling pin.
Heat a skillet or griddle over medium heat. Place a chapati on the skillet and cook until bubbles form, about 1-2 minutes.
Flip the chapati and cook for another 1-2 minutes, until golden brown spots appear on both sides.
Repeat with the remaining dough balls, stacking the cooked chapatis on a plate and covering them with a clean kitchen towel to keep warm.
Serve hot with butter or ghee, if desired. Enjoy the soft and flaky goodness of Kenyan Chapati!
